name: Prereg Prize

messages.beforeSubmitForApproval: You are about to submit your study and analysis for review. This will notify Prereg Prize Administrators who will begin to review it. You will still be able to edit this registration but must submit again. Are you sure you are ready for review?
messages.afterSubmitForApproval: You have successfully submitted your study and analysis plans. Next, staff from the Center for Open Science will have the plans reviewed to assure that enough detail was included. Reviewers may accept your plans or request revisions. Remember, in order to be eligible for the Prere Prize, your plans must be accepted through this review process. We will contact you within five business days with a status update. If you have any questions, please contact prereg@cos.io and we will be happy to help you.

description: Pre-Registration Prize (pre-data collection): You will be asked a series of questions to ensure that your sampling, design, and analysis plans are solidified prior to beginning your study. Publications that pre-register with this template may be eligible for a $1,000 prize. See project page for complete information.

q01.title: Title
q01.description: What is the working title of your study? It is helpful if this is the same title that you submit for publication of your final manuscript, but it is not a requirement.
q01.help: Effect of sugar on brownie tastiness.

q02.title: Authorship
q02.description: The first author of the pre-registered study is the recipient of the award money and must also be the first author of the published manuscript. Additional authors may be added or removed at any time.
q02.help: Jimmy Stewart, Ava Gardner, Bob Hope, Greta Garbo

q03.title: Conflict of Interest
q03.description: Could the results of this project benefit the financial interests of any of its authors, or be reasonably perceived to do so?
q03.help: The authors of this study own a majority share of Tastee Sugar Company.

q04.title: Research questions and hypotheses
q04.description: What are your research questions and hypotheses? Both directional and non-directional hypotheses are acceptable.
q04.help: There is strong evidence to suggest that sugar affects taste preferences, but the effect has never been demonstrated in brownies. Therefore, we will measure taste preference for four different levels of sugar concentration in a standard brownie recipe. If taste effects preferences, then mean preference indices will be higher with higher concentrations of sugar.

q05.title: Data collection procedures
q05.description: Please describe the process by which you will collect your data. If you are using human subjects, this should include the population from which you obtain subjects, recruitment efforts, payment for participation, how subjects will be selected for eligibility from the initial pool (e.g. inclusion and exclusion rules), and your study timeline. For studies that don√ït include human subjects, include information about how you will collect samples, duration of data gathering efforts, or batch numbers you will use.
q05.help: Participants will be recruited through advertisements at local pastry shops. Participants will be paid $10 for agreeing to  participating (raised to $30 if our sample size is not reached within 15 days of beginning recruitment). Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to eat the ingredients of the pastries.

q06.title: Sample size
q06.description: What is your sample size? How many units will be analyzed in the study? This could be the number of people, birds, classrooms, plots, interactions, or countries included. If the units are not individuals, then describe the size requirements for each unit. If you are using a clustered or multilevel design, how many units are you collecting at each level of the analysis?
q06.help: Our target sample size is 280 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 320, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q07.title: Sample size rationale
q07.description: This could include a power analysis or an arbitrary constraint such as resource availability. Include a stopping rule.
q07.help: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. We will stop recruiting participants at 320 (to account for incomplete data) or after 30 days, whichever comes first.

q08.title: Please check and certify one of the following statements

options: I certify that none of the data that will be used in this upcoming study have yet been collected. Please enter your name and the phrase I certify in the following box. Why is this necessary?

I will be using pre-existing data in this study. I certify that I have no knowledge about any of its basic descriptive statistics, nor am I aware of any differences or relationships within the data that I will use. Please enter your name and the phrase I certify in the following boxes.

q09.title: Study type
options: Experiment (A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment or a randomized controlled trial.
Observational Study (Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, natural experiments, and regression discontinuity designs.)
Meta-Analysis (a systematic review of published studies)

q10.title: Blinding
options: Not applicable: This study will not assign treatments to subjects (e.g. observational studies or meta-analyses).
Yes, single blind: Human subjects of the study will not know if they are assigned to a treatment or control group. Experimenters will have that knowledge.
Yes, double blind: Neither the human subjects, nor the experimenters taking measurements from a subject will have knowledge of the treatment.
No: both human subjects and researchers are aware of the treatment groups.
Yes: I am using non-human study subjects, and researchers collecting data are ignorant of each subject¬ês treatment group.
No: researchers are aware of the treatment groups.

q11.title: Study design
q11.description: Describe your study design. Examples include two-group, factorial, randomized block, and repeated measures. Is it a between or within-subject design? Describe any counterbalancing required. Typical study designs for observation studies include cohort, cross sectional, and case-control studies. You will be asked to define your variables in detail in the upcoming sections.
q11.help: In our between-subject design, each of the 280 expected participants will taste one of the four levels of brownies (1X4)

q12.title: Predictor variable(s)
q12.description: Define your predictor or independent variable(s). If you have categorical predictors, describe the levels for each. If your predictor variables are constructed from multiple measurements, you will be asked later on to describe how they are created.
q12.help: Our predictor is the amount of sugar added per brownie. The dry ingredients for each brownie will contain 15%, 20%, 25%, or 40% cane sugar by mass.

q13.title: Outcome variable(s)
q13.description: Define your outcome or dependent variable(s). If your outcome measurements are constructed from multiple measurements, you will be asked later on to describe how they are created.
q13.help: The single outcome variable will be the perceived tastiness of the single brownie each participant will eat.

q14.title: Covariates.
q14.description: Describe any covariates. If applicable, and not mentioned above, what covariates, controls, or other independent variables will you measure?
q14.help: We will be collecting basic demographic information from each participant (age, household income, education level, housing zipcode, and marital status) and use that information for exploratory data investigation to determine if taste perception may be easily predicted. Any suggestive correlations may be the subject of future, confirmatory investigations.

q15.title: If you are doing a randomized study, how will you randomize, and at what level? There are many different randomization techniques.
q15.description: If you are doing a randomized study, how will you randomize, and at what level? There are many different randomization techniques.
q15.help: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined blocks. The random number list used to create these four blocks will e created using the web applications available at http://random.org.

q16.title: Constructing predictor variables
q16.description: Sometimes, a main predictor will not be a single measurement, but an index made from several other measurements. What measures will you use and how will they be combined to make your predictor variable(s).
q16.help: The predictor variable (percent sugar) will not be constructed from multiple measures.

q17.title: Constructing outcome variables
q17.description: Just as with the previous question, how will specific measures be combined to create your outcome variable(s)?
q17.help: As taste perception is a complex variable, we will measure it by taking each users geometric mean response from three widely used indices of tastiness: the Tasty Measure Index of Sweetness (1-100 scale), the Yum Scale of Enjoyability (1-10 scale), and the Aural Pleasure Rating of Foods (1-20 scale). A geometric mean will be used because of the scale variation between each of the three indices.

q18.title: Data exclusion
q18.description: How will you determine what data or samples (if any) to exclude from your analyses? How will outliers be handled? You may want to attach a decision tree with an 'if, then' structure to easily formalize the way in which these decisions will be made.
q18.help: No checks will be performed to determine eligibility for inclusion besides verification that each subject answered each of the three tastiness indices. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q19.title: Incomplete or missing data
q19.description: How will you deal with incomplete or missing data? Many studies will have missing data points. How you cope with these missing points is important because it can affect the result of your analysis.
q19.help: If any of the three indices of tastiness are not completed by a subject, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q20.title: Statistical model
q20.description: What statistical model(s) will you use to test your hypothesis(ses)? Please include the type of model (e.g. ANOVA, regression, SEM, etc) as well as the specification of the model (e.g. what variables will be included, and if they will be transformed or centered in any way). If you are using a method other than null hypothesis significance testing, such as a Bayesian method, provide the criteria you will use for making an evidence-based conclusion. Include likely alternative analyses or data transformations. This may be another item where a decision tree could be helpful.
q20.help: We will use a 1x4 ANOVA to analyze our results. The categorical independent variable is sugar‚Äù whereas the dependent variable, taste,‚Äù is continuous. If the the ANOVA indicates that the mean taste perceptions are significantly different (p<.05), then we will use a Tukey-Kramer HSD test to determine the differences between levels. We will test the assumption of the ANOVA on equal group variance using the Bartlett test and use a Kruskal-Wallis if p<.05.

q21.title: Multiple comparisons
q21.description: If you are comparing multiple conditions or testing multiple hypotheses, how will you account for this?
q21.help: The only possible instance of requiring adjustment or acknowledgement of multiple comparisons would be the six combinations among the four levels of the independent variable tested in the ANOVA, which will only be investigated if indicated by the ANOVA results by a Tukey HSD.

q22.title: (Optional) Upload an analysis script with clear comments.
q22.description: (Optional) Upload an analysis script with clear comments. This optional step is helpful in order to create a process that is completely transparent and increase the likelihood that your analysis can be replicated. We recommend that you run the code on a simulated dataset in order to check that it will run without errors.
q22.help: Here is a link to the R script that we will use to run the ANOVA. It also contains the code for the Tukey HSD we will run if needed. https://osf.io/kexgi/
